page.title: 18THE NATURAL HABITAT
page.content: The area is chalk with no surface water. Arable farmland covers most of the area and there are few grazing animals. Natural cover for wildlife still exists in several forms mainly hedgerows and isolated coverts. Dr Hooper's formular was used to date the hedgerows i.e.Age of Hedge=(Number of Species x 110) + 30 years. The hedges average 5 or 6 species in such a strtch suggesting an age of about 550 years. Archive evidence is unavailable to confirm this but the age of local settlements and the sunken nature of some lanes suggests that they could be even older. Hawthorn is the most common species. A visit to Gifford's Covert GR 326455 showed it to be a heavily overgrown area of deciduous woodland. The trees are covered in creepers and the lowlying ground is damp moss_covered clay.
